characters: HAROLD AND MAUDE ON A MERRY-GO-ROUND

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CAMERA is at floor level. A young man enters but we see only his shoes and the cuffs of his pants. We TRACK with him as he walks across the room and stops at a recor player. Pause. We HEAR a record drop and begin playing a light classical melody. The SUPERIMPOSED TITLES BEGIN. After a moment the feet move off and we TRACK with them, past a low table, and around a couch to the window curtai The feet pause there for a moment. A piece of heavy window cord drops INTO FRAME. We FOLLOW as it is dragged along to the low table. Then the feet move over to a larg ornate desk. The cord is pulled up OUT OF FRAME. Pause. The feet walk over to a chair by the wall. It is picked up, carried to the center of the room, and carefully placed. Pause. The feet get up onto the chair and the CAMERA RISES to their level. They shuffle about for a moment. At an appropriate musical break the CREDITS STOP. Suddenly the feet knock over the chair and drop into space. They kick about for a bit, then go slack and still The FINAL CREDITS are SUPERED OVER the suspended appendag while the music comes to a lilting conclusion. As we HEAR the record player turn itself off, the CAMERA BEGINS a half circle tour around the hanging feet and stops at the heels. Pause. Outside we HEAR a woman's footsteps approaching and we change focus as the door to the den opens. Through the blurred hanging feet we see a tall, middle-aged, fashionably dressed woman enter and we PAN with her as she walks to the desk. This is MRS. CHASEN. She seems rather tired and preoccupied as she begins to remove her long white gloves. Slowly the CAMERA BEGINS a vertical rise up the side of the hanging corpse until we are watching Mrs. Chasen over his left shoulder. The rope and his stretched neck frame the right side of the SCREEN We hold. Mrs. Chasen puts down her gloves and looks up. (NOTE: THE ABOVE IS ALL ONE CONTINUOUS SHOT.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSEUP of Mrs. Chasen as she first sees the body. She is slightly startled.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: A long shot of the room where HAROLD, a young man of abou twenty, hangs suspended from the ceiling with the curtain rope tied about his grotesquely broken neck. haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay txt 1/105  3/6/12 4 haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay.txt

dialogues.speaker: MRS. CHASEN
dialogues.text: She stares at the body for several beats and then with weary exasperation sits down at the desk and dials the telephone. As she waits for an answer, she looks up at th hanging body.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. CHASEN
dialogues.text: I suppose you think this is very funny, Harold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rope chokes his throat; his eyes bulge; his tongue hangs out.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. CHASEN
dialogues.text: Her party answers and she speaks into the phone.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. CHASEN
dialogues.text: Hello. Fay, darling. Be a dear and cancel my appointment with Rene this afternoon. Yes, I know he'll be furious, but I've had the most trying day, and with guests coming this evening... Would you? Oh, that's sweet. Tell him I promise to be in Tuesday... for a rinse. Thank you, Fay. You're a darling. Yes. Yes. Bye. She replaces the receiver, stands up, takes her purse and gloves, and leaves the room, saying:

dialogues.speaker: MRS. CHASEN
dialogues.text: Dinner at eight, Harold... At the door she stops and turns.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. CHASEN
dialogues.text: And try to be a little more

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: vivacious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quick cut of his ashen face as we HEAR the door close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Chasen is seated at the head of the table entertaini eight to ten guests. haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay txt 2/105 3/6/12 haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay.tx They are all in evening clothes and are laughing as Mrs. Chasen in a dress of white ostrich feathers continues a witty story.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. CHASEN
dialogues.text: Needless to say, the first time i happened I was absolutely abashed. I was so shook I needed three tranquilizers to calm me down. Well, you can imagine. Suicide notes all over the house - "Goodbye," "Farewell," "Arrivederci." Other children pretend to run away from home, but Harold - he's so dramatic. Everyone laughs. The CAMERA BEGINS PULLING BACK and PANNING past the guests till we come to Harold sitting morosely at the other end of the table. He listlessly toy with his food as his mother continues.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. CHASEN
dialogues.text: Of course, Harold's father had a similar sense of the absurd. I remember once in Paris he stepped out for cigarettes and the next I hear he's arrested for floating nude down the Seine - experimenting in river currents with a pair of yellow rubber water wings. Well, that cost quite a little bit of "enfluence" and "d'argent" to hush up, I can tell you. Harold, dear, stop playing with your food. Don't you feel well?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: (looks up and pauses) I have a sore throat.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. CHASEN
dialogues.text: Well, I want you to go to bed directly after dinner. You know how susceptible you are to colds. Harold has always been a delicate child. Even as a baby he seemed to be abnormally prone to illness - Harold, dear, eat up your beets...

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: He begins eating as his mother goes on. MRS. CHASEN (0.s.) I remember when we were in Tokyo haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay txt
3/6/12 10 12 haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay. txt I had to call my brother Victor at the embassy for a doctor. He was serving there as Army attachГ©... FADE OUT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Chasen sitting before her vanity table, humming to herself as she readies herself for bed. She wears a night gown, a cover for her hair, and she has just finished putting on several different face creams. She gets up, walks over to the bathroom, and opens the door. Blood is everywhere -- on the walls, the floor, the mirror - and i the tub is Harold, his throat slit and his wrists drippin blood onto the razor on the tile floor. The effect is one of instant shock. Mrs. Chasen screams and backs up in horror. Sobbing hysterically, she clutches her robe about her and rushes from the room crying.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. CHASEN
dialogues.text: Oh! No! Oh! No! I can't stand it. My God! This is too much. This is too much to bear!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CAMERA WATCHES Mrs. Chasen run off and then swings ba to Harold in the tub.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: We hold on his wretched face as his mother's hysterical cries are heard in the background. Harold moves his head and listens. He breaks into a sly, satisfied grin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harold is lying on a couch, perfectly relaxed. The PSYCHIATRIST, less so, is seated by him.

dialogues.speaker: PSYCHIATRIST
dialogues.text: Tell me, Harold, how many of these, eh, suicides have you performed?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: (pause) An accurate number would be difficult to gauge.

dialogues.speaker: PSYCHIATRIST
dialogues.text: And why is that? haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay txt 4/105  3/6/12 13 14 haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay.txt

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Well, some worked out better than others - some had to be abandoned in the planning stages - do you include the first time? - then there's the question of maiming...

dialogues.speaker: PSYCHIATRIST
dialogues.text: Just give me a rough estimate.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Well, a rough estimate... I'd say fifteen.

dialogues.speaker: PSYCHIATRIST
dialogues.text: Fifteen.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: A rough estimate.

dialogues.speaker: PSYCHIATRIST
dialogues.text: And were they all done for your mother's benefit?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: (thoughtful pause) I wouldn't say "benefit."

dialogues.speaker: PSYCHIATRIST
dialogues.text: No, I suppose not. How do you feel about your mother?

dialogues.speaker: STOCK
dialogues.text: A giant steel ball on a demolition crane crashes into a brick wall collapsing it with much noise and dust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Chasen decked out in a fashionable black bikini, cra glasses, and an enormous sun hat, walks down the garden steps to the pool. Over this and the end of the above we HEAR her voice. MRS. CHASEN (v.o.) Hello, Fay, darling. Be an absolute dear and cancel my appointment with Rene this afternoon. Oh, I know, but Wednesday morning would be so much more convenient. Oh, you are an angel. Yes. Yes. Bye. haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay txt 5/105  3/6/12 15 16 17 18 haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay.txt Mrs. Chasen has now reached the poolside. As she walks around it we PAN with her and discover Harold, fully clothed, floating face downward on the still surface. Mrs Chasen does not see him and walks into the pool house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Chasen walks down the steps of the pool house and ov to the bar. Behind the bar is an underwater viewing window into the pool. She stops and looks up through the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the window we see Harold, drowned and bug-eyed, floating on the surface.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. CHASEN
dialogues.text: Mrs. Chasen sighs, yanks a cord, and the venetian blinds come noisily down cutting off Harold from view.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harold is lying on the couch.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: (a reasoned assessment) I don't think I'm getting through to Mother like I used to.

dialogues.speaker: PSYCHIATRIST
dialogues.text: Does that worry you?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: (pause) Yes. It does.

dialogues.speaker: PSYCHIATRIST
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I put a lot of effort into these things.

dialogues.speaker: PSYCHIATRIST
dialogues.text: Ah, yes.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: And a lot of time. haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay txt
3/6/12 19 20 haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay. txt

dialogues.speaker: PSYCHIATRIST
dialogues.text: I'm sure. But what else do you do with your time? Do you go to school?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: PSYCHIATRIST
dialogues.text: What about the draft?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: My mother spoke to my Uncle Victor. He's in the Army and he fixed it up.

dialogues.speaker: PSYCHIATRIST
dialogues.text: Oh. Well, how do you spend your day?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: You mean when I'm not working on a...

dialogues.speaker: PSYCHIATRIST
dialogues.text: Yes. What kind of things do you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cranes, auto smashers, bulldozers, and mountains of rusti cars and other junk. Very noisy and very fast cut. A little essay on destructive machinery at work with Harold looking on in rapture.

dialogues.speaker: PSYCHIATRIST
dialogues.text: I see. Junkyards. What is the fascination there?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: PSYCHIATRIST
dialogues.text: Is it the machines? The noise? The people?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: No. It's the junk. I like to look at junk.

dialogues.speaker: PSYCHIATRIST
dialogues.text: What else do you like? Harold pauses. haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay txt 7/105  3/6/12 21 22 23 24 25 haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay.txt

dialogues.speaker: STOCK
dialogues.text: A giant steel ball crashes into a building. We watch it fall noisily into dust and rubble.

dialogues.speaker: PSYCHIATRIST
dialogues.text: That's very interesting, Harold, and I think very illuminative. There seems to be a definite pattern emerging. (taking copious notes) Your fondness for useless machines and demolitions seems indicative of your present emotional state, your self-destructive urges and your alienation from the regular social interaction. What do you think? And of course this pattern once isolated can be coped with. Recognize the problem and you are half way on the road to its solution. But tell me, what do you do for fun? What activity gives you a different sense of enjoyment than the others? What do you find fulfilling? What gives you that certain satisfaction?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I go to funerals.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: showing a small group of mourners around a grave. A nearb bench by a tree is empty. The coffin is slowly being lowered into the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSER SHOTS of the mourners sobbing and the priest pray- ing. We come to Harold who has a look of gentle fascina- tion. The service is concluding. Harold looks up across the grave. A hundred yards away on the cemetery bench sits an old woman eating a tangerine. This is MAUDE. Harold stares at her. She seems to be having some kind of happy picnic. She looks over towards him. He quickly returns his attention to the burial.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Chasen opens the front door and is saying farewell t haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay txt 8/105 3/6/12 haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay.tx two lady friends, the same kind of chic sophisticates as she is. Just then a hearse pulls into the driveway passes them, and parks by the garage. The two women are somewhat stunned. Harold gets out of the hearse and goes into the backyard. The two women look to Mrs. Chasen for some explanation. Mrs. Chasen smiles lamely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Chasen is addressing a seated and mute Harold.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. CHASEN
dialogues.text: Why you purchased that monstrous thing is totally beyond me. You can have any car you want - a Porsche, a Jaguar, a nice little MG roadster - but that ugly, black horror is an eyesore and an embarrassment. Really, Harold, you are no longer a child. It's time for you to settle down and stop flitting away your talents on these amateur theatrics - your little "divertissements" - no matter how psychologically purging they may be. I don't know what to do.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE VICTOR
dialogues.text: I'd put him in the Army, Helen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Chasen continues.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. CHASEN
dialogues.text: Go have a talk with your Uncle Victor. Perhaps he can fathom you. After all, he was General Bradley's right hand man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: UNCLE VICTOR, a bluff, hearty, totally military man, is a one star general with an amputated right arm. Harold sits before him.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE VICTOR
dialogues.text: Harold, your mother has briefed me on your situation and there is no doubt in my mind of the requisite necessary action. If it was up to haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay txt 9/105  3/6/12 30 He pulls his lanyard, haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay.txt me I'd process your file and ship you off to boot camp tomorrow. Your mother, however, is adamant. She does not want you in the Army and insists on my holding on to your draft records. But what do you say, Harold? (he begins a selling job) It's a great life. Action! Adventure! Advising. See war - firsthand! Plenty of slant-eyed girls. It will make a man out of you, Harold. You'll travel the world. Put on the uniform and take on a man's job. Walk tall! - with a glint in your eye, a spring in your step, and the knowledge in your heart that you are - (he gestures to a poster of bullet-вЂ” blazing Marines) - working for peace, and - are serving your country.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stops before a poster of Nathan Hale with a noose his neck.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE VICTOR
dialogues.text: (continuing) Like Nathan Hale. That's what this country needs - more Nathan Hales.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE VICTOR
dialogues.text: (softly) And, Harold, I think I can see a little Nathan Hale in you.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. CHASEN
dialogues.text: I only have a few minutes, Harold, but I do want to inform you of my decision. There is no doubt that it is time for you to settle down and begin thinking about your future. You have led a very carefree, idle, happy life up to the present - the life of a child. But it is time now to put away childish things and take on adult haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay txt about activating some weird mechanism which snaps up his empty sleeve into a natty salute. A pause. The sleeve smartly refolds and he turns to Harold. Chasen is going out, but she comes in to talk to Harold. 10/105  3/6/12 31 32 33 haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay. txt responsibilities. We would all like to sail through life with no thought of tomorrow. But that cannot be. We have our duty. Our obligations. Our principles. In short, Harold, I think it is time you got married.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PAN DOWN from the stained glass window of a church. The organ is playing softly. The PRIEST, a silver haired man rapidly approaching dotage, is in the pulpit.

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST
dialogues.text: And so dear brethren, let us pray to the Lord, King of Glory, that He may bless and deliver all souls of the faithful departed from the pains of hell and the bottomless pit, deliver them from the lion's mouth and the darkness therein, but rather bring them to the bliss of heaven, the holy light, and eternal rest. During the above we PULL BACK to reveal an open coffin an a church spreckled with a few mourners in black. Con- spicuous in an empty pew is Harold. The priest goes to the altar and mumbles the dull ritual. The small congregation responds. Harold sits quietly enjoying it all. VOICE (o.s.) Psst! Harold, startled, looks over to his left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pixiesque old woman, somewhat eccentrically dressed, is smiling at him. It is Maude again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frowning slightly, Harold turns back front.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: Psst. Harold looks back. haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay txt 14/105 3/6/12 haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay.tx

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maude gives him a coquettish wink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harold is slightly shocked. He returns his attention to the altar.

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST
dialogues.text: The priest moans on.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Harold sits attentively. VOICE (o.s.) Psst! Harold, startled, looks over his right shoulder and sees Maude kneeling in the pew behind him. She speaks with a slight British/European accent.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: Like some licorice? She offers some.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Eh, no. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: You're welcome. (gesturing to the deceased) Did you know him?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Eh, no.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: Me neither. I heard he was eighty years old. I'll be eighty next week. A good time to move on, don't you think?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: (trying to ignore her) I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: I mean, seventy-five is too early, haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay txt 12/105  3/6/12 38 40 41 haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay. txt but at eighty-five, well, you're just marking time and you may as well look over the horizon.

dialogues.speaker: ALTAR
dialogues.text: The priest finishes the prayers and exits. The casket is closed and the pallbearers take it out the side door. The few mourners follow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maude is now sitting next to Harold.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: I'll never understand this mania for black. I mean no one sends black flowers, do they? Black flowers are dead flowers and who would send black flowers to a funeral? It's change! (fluttery laugh) How absurd. Her eye catches a dour portrait of the Blessed Virgin and Child on a pillar. With one swoop she takes a felt pen from Harold's breast pocket and draws on the painting a bright and cheery smile. Harold is stunned.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: There, that's better. They never give the poor thing a chance to laugh. Heaven knows she has a lot to be happy about. In fact... (she looks thought- fully around the church) - they all have a lot to be happy about. Excuse me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The faces of four somber statue saints. MAUDE (v.o.) An unhappy saint is a contradiction in terms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An anxious Harold stands while Maude puts the top back on his pen. Maude smiles and gestures at a crucifix.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay txt 13/105  3/6/12 42 43 44 haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay.txt And why do they keep on about that? You'd think no one ever read the end of the story. She exits grandly with Harold's pen. Harold follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FOUR QUICK CUTS of the saints' faces. They all have delightfully ridiculous smiles drawn on their faces.

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST
dialogues.text: In the same rhythm we have a FIFTH CUT - the returning priest who is dropped dead by what he sees.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: It's a question of emphasis, you might say. Accentuate the positive, so to speak.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Eh, could I have my pen back now, please?

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: Oh, of course. What is your name?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Harold Chasen.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: How do you do? I am Dame Marjorie Chardin, but you may call me Maude.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Nice to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: Oh, thank you. I think we shall be great friends, don't you? Maude takes a great ring of keys from her purse, selects one of them, and opens the door of the car at the curb.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: Can I drop you anywhere, Harold?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: (quickly) No, thank you. I have my car.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay txt 14/105  3/6/12 45 haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay. txt Well then, I must be off. (she gets in) We shall have to meet again. She revs up the motor and looks over at Harold.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: Do you dance?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: Do you sing and dance?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Eh, no.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: No. (she smiles) I thought not. With a great screech of burning rubber Maude drives down the street just as the priest comes up to Harold. They both watch her squeal around the corner.

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST
dialogues.text: (totally mystified) That woman... She took my car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harold is sitting in a chair. His mother enters and sits down at the desk.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. CHASEN
dialogues.text: I have here, Harold, the forms sent out by the National Computer Dating Service. It seems to me that as you do not get along with the daughters of my friends this is the best way for you to find a prospective wife. Harold starts to say something.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. CHASEN
dialogues.text: (continuing) Please, Harold, we have a lot to do and I have to be at the hairdresser's at three. (she looks over the papers) The Computer Dating Service offers you at least three dates haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay txt 15/105  3/6/12 haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay.txt on the initial investment. They screen out the fat and ugly so it is obviously a firm of high standards. I'm sure they can find you at least one girl who is compatible. Now first, here is the personality interview which you are to fill out and return. There are fifty questions with five possible responses to check... "A - Absolutely Yes, B - Yes, C - Not sure, D - No, E - Absolutely No." Are you ready, Harold? The first question is "Are you uncomfortable meeting new people?" Well, I think that's a "yes." Don't you agree, Harold? Even an "Absolutely yes." We'll put down "A" on that. Now, number two. "Do you believe it is acceptable for women to initiate dates with men?" Well, absolutely. Mark " on that. "Three - Should sex education be taught outside the home?" I would say no, wouldn't you, Harold? Give a "D" there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chasen continues filling out Harold's questionnaire without hardly ever even looking over for his reaction. He sits there, watching.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. CHASEN
dialogues.text: "Four - Do you often invite friends to your home?" Now, you never do, Harold. Absolutely no. "Five - Do you enjoy participating in clubs and social organizations?" You don't, do you? Absolutely no. "Six - Do you enjoy spending a lot of time by yourself?" Absolutely yes. Mark "A." "Seven - Should women run for President of the United States?" I don't see why not. Absolutely yes. "Eight вЂ” Do you have ups and downs without obvious reason?" You do, don't you, Harold? Absolutely yes. "Nine - Do you remember jokes and take pleasure in relating them to others?" You don't, do you, Harold? Absolutely no. "Ten - Do you often get the feeling that perhaps life isn't worth living?" Hmm. What do you think, Harold? haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay txt 16/105 3/6/12 haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay.tx Harold looks blankly back at his mother.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. CHASEN
dialogues.text: (continuing) "A"? "B"2 We'll put down "C" - "Not sure." "Eleven - Is the subject of sex being over-exploited by our mass media?" That would have to be "Yes," wouldn't it? "Twelve - Do you think judges favor some lawyers?" Yes, I suppose they do. "Thirteen - .... Harold sits passively in his chair. Slowly he draws a revolver from his pocket. As his mother rattles on he ver deliberately loads the bullets one by one into the chambe

dialogues.speaker: MRS. CHASEN
dialogues.text: Is it difficult for you to accept criticism?" Nooo. We'll mark "D." "Fourteen - Do you sometimes have headaches or back aches after a difficult day?" Yes, I do indeed. "Fifteen - Do you go to sleep easily?" I'd say so. "Sixteen - Do you believe in capital punishment for murder?" Oh, yes. "Seventeen - Do you believe churches have a strong influence to upgrade the general morality?" - yes, again. "Eighteen - In your opinion are social affairs usually a waste of time?" Heavens, no! "Nineteen - Can God influence our lives?" Yes. Absolutely yes. "Twenty - Have you ever crossed the street to avoid meeting someone?" Well, I'm sure you have, haven't you, Harold? "Twenty-one - Would you prefer to be with a group of people rather than alone?" That's you, Harold. "Twenty-two - Is it acceptable for a schoolteacher to smoke or drink in public?" Well, with reservation. Mark "B." "Twenty-three..." Having finished loading the gun, Harold cocks it and, looking at his mother, slowly lifts it up.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. CHASEN

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: Then I suppose it was me. Get in, Harold. Harold decides not to argue. He gets

Maude drives like a haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay txt 19/105 3/6/12 haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay.tx racing car driver, fast and risky, but with complete self assurance.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: What a delight it is, Harold, to bump into you again. I knew we were going to be good friends the moment I saw you. You go to funerals often, don't you? Harold is more intent on Maude's maneuvering of his car than on conversation.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.text: Oh, so do I. They're such fun, aren't they? It's all change. All revolving. Burials and births. The end to the beginning and the beginning to the end - (she makes a screeching left- hand turn) - the great circle of life. My, this old thing handles well. Ever drive a hearse, Harold?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: (petrified) Yes.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: Well, it's a new experience for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (she makes a screech- ing right-hand turn) Good on curves. Shall I take you home, Harold?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: (managing to speak) But this is my car.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: Your hearse?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Yearse!

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: of the car coming to a screeching halt. haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay txt 20/105 3/6/12 haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay.tx

dialogues.text: SAME ANGLE as 49 but this time Harold is driving and Maud sits beside him.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: And so just before he left for the monastery in Tibet, Big Sweeney gave me his keys. She is showing Harold her ring of car keys.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: (continuing) Of course, I've had to make some additions for the new models, but not as many as you might think. Once you have your basic set it's then only a question of variation.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: And you get into any car you want and just drive off?

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: Not any car. I like to keep a variety. I'm always looking for the new experience, like this one. I liked it.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Thank you. But when you take these cars don't you think you are wronging the owners?

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: What owners, Harold? We don't own anything. It's a transitory world. We come on the earth with nothing, and we go out with not so isn't "ownership" a little absurd?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Still, I think you'd upset people and I'm not sure that right.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay txt 21/105. 3/6/12 haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay.tx Well, if some people are upset because they feel they have a hold on some things, then I'm merely acting as a gentle reminder - I'm sort of breaking it easy -- Here today, gone tomorrow, so don't get attached to things. Now, with tha in mind, I'm not against collecting stuff...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maude and Harold enter.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: I've collected quite a lot of stuff in my time. We see Maude's main room filled with all kinds of eccentr memorabilia, from a mounted swordfish to an ivory Buddha. It is dominated by a large canopied bed like something fr a Wagnerian opera. Other features are a large fireplace, a baby grand piano, expensive paintings on the walls, a tall wooden sculpture, and a Japanese type eating area wi satin cushions.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: It's all memorabilia, but incidental and not integral, if you know what I mean.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: (looks around amazed) It's very interesting.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: Oh, look! The birds. She goes to the window and works a unique pulley device t delivers seed to the bird table in the back yard.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: This is my daily ritual. I love them so much. The only wild life I see anymore. Free as a bird! (fluttery laugh) You know, at one time I used to break into pet shops and liberate the canaries, but I gave it up as an idea before its time. The zoos are full and the prisons overflowing. My, my. How the world so dearly loves a cage. (she looks out haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay txt 22/105 3/6/12 haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay.tx another window) And there's Madame Arouet, cultivating her garden. She waves at the black dressed old woman diligently hoein vegetables in the backyard. The old woman does not notice Maude.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: (sighs) She's very sweet, but so old- fashioned. Please sit down, Harold. I'll put on the kettle and we'll have a nice hot cup of tea.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Thank you, but I really have to go.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: But it's oat straw tea. You've never had oat straw tea, have you?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: No

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: Well then. The argument is over.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Thank you, but it's an appointment. I really shouldn't miss it.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: Oh, at the dentist's?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Sort of.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: Well, then, you must come back and visit.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: All right.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: My door is always open.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: All right.

dialogues.text: Promise? haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay txt 23/105.  3/6/12 54 haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay.txt He turns at the door and half smiles.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Promise.

dialogues.text: Harold is on the couch. The psychiat

dialogues.text: Harold? Harold is day dreaming.

dialogues.text: Harold?

dialogues.text: (comes to) Huh?

dialogues.text: No

dialogues.text: Would you care to talk about this friend?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: No

dialogues.text: (things are getting difficult) I see. (he tries a new attack) Were you happy at school, Harold? haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay txt ist sits behind him. 24/105. 3/6/12 haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay.tx

dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.text: Your classmates?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.text: Your studies?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I burnt down the Chemistry building. The psychiatrist gets up and rather anxiously paces about

dialogues.text: We are not relating today, Harold. I sense a definite resistance. A lack of true and helpful communication. I find you a very interesting case, Harold, but this reluctance of yours is detrimental to the psycho-analytical process, and can only hinder the possibility of effective treatment. Do you understand?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: PSYCHIATRIST
dialogues.text: Very well. (he sits) Now your mother tells me she is arranging several dates for you with some young ladies. How do you feel about that?

dialogues.text: A giant steel ball crashes into a brick wall, demolishing it. haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay txt 25/105  3/6/12 56 57 58 59 haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay.txt

dialogues.text: No. (pause) I'd have liked to.

dialogues.text: why?

dialogues.text: All the lights are on showing a room cluttered with books guns and swords on the walls, small bits of odd machinery a chemistry workbench, a school pennant, some trophies, some models, a chess set, etc. HAROLD (v.o.) Oh, all my things - incidental but not integral, if you know what I mean. We PAN over individual items - the chemistry set, pool floats, a small oxygen cylinder, the rope and body harnes he used to hang himself in the first scene, a large bottl of Max Factor blood, a portrait of Lon Chaney as "The Phantom of the Opera." We come to a silver serving dish with a large silver cove over it. A hand comes into frame and removes the cover. On the dish is Harold's severed head. The hands pick up haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay txt 26/105  3/6/12 60 haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay. txt the head. We TILT UP and see it is Harold. He takes the dummy head over to his dresser, combs the hair and picks off the latex blood, and then takes it to the center of t room, where a headless dummy sits in a chair. Harold scre the head onto the dummy. It doesn't fit very well. He fiddles with it a moment but he is not satisfied. He goes to his closet and looks into a box of tools and things. He takes a meat cleaver out but he is still looking for something else. There is a knock on the door and Mrs. Chasen in evening clothes enters. Harold turns to come ou of the closet but he hears his mother addressing the dumm

dialogues.text: Now listen, Harold, I have here the three girls sent out by the Computer Dating Service. She shuffles through three IBM cards in her hand.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. CHASEN
dialogues.text: (continuing) I've phoned them up and invited each of them to have lunch with us before you take them out. The first one is coming tomorrow at one. Luncheon at two. Harold stands with the meat cleaver in his hand behind th closet door. He listens blankly.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. CHASEN
dialogues.text: (still talking to the dummy) Now I want you to act like a gentleman and make this girl feel at home. Well, I'm off to the ballet with the Fergusons. I only hope they can maneuver round that great black thing in the driveway. (she pauses) You look a little pale, Harold. (she opens the door) You get a good night's sleep. After all you want to look your best for tomorrow. (she exits) Harold hears the door shut. He ponders his fate for a moment. He leans around the door and looks at the dummy. He thinks. He gives it up. He goes back in the closet to find whatever he was looking for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay txt 27/105 3/6/12 haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay.tx Mrs. Chasen opens the front door, revealing a cute, typical American co-ed. This is CANDY GULF.

dialogues.text: Hello, I'm Candy Gulf.

dialogues.text: (continuing) Harold is out in the garden. He'll be in in a moment. Let's go into the den.

dialogues.text: You are at the University, Candy?

dialogues.text: Yes, I am.

dialogues.text: And what are you studying?

dialogues.text: Poli. Sci. With a home ec minor.

dialogues.text: Eh, Poli Sci?

dialogues.speaker: CANDY
dialogues.text: Political Science. It's all about what's going on. They walk to the window.

dialogues.text: Oh, there's Harold now. Candy and Mrs. Chasen look out the French window. wave. Harold waves back and leaves. Candy and Mrs. sit down. Candy faces the window; Mrs. Chasen has her back to it.

dialogues.text: He seems very nice. Is Harold interested in, eh, what's going on? I think it's such a super thing to study. And then, of haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay txt 28/105. 3/6/12 haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay.tx course, I can always fall back on home ec.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. CHASEN
dialogues.text: Yes, that's good planning. Tell me, are you a regular, Candy, in this computer club? We see out the window that Harold has come back. He carri a large can marked Kerosene. Candy sees him but returns her attention to answering Mrs. Chasen.

dialogues.speaker: CANDY
dialogues.text: Heavens no. I don't have to worry about dates. You see, the other girls in my sorority, well, we decided that somebody should try it, so we drew straws and I lost. (little giggle) But I am looking forward to meeting Harold. She looks beyond Mrs. Chasen, out the window. She is a little nonplussed. Harold is pouring the kerosene all ove himself.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. CHASEN
dialogues.text: I think I should mention, Candy, that Harold does have his eccentric moments.

dialogues.speaker: CANDY
dialogues.text: (never let it be said that she isn't a good sport) Oh, yes? Well, that's all right. I've got a brother who's a real cut-up, too. I'll never forget the time we had this old TV set with no parts in it. Well, Tommy stuck his head behind it and started giving a newscast before the whole family. We were all hysterical. And here's little Tommy pretending to be Walter Cronkite. She looks back at Harold out the window. He is ablaze. Her mouth falls open.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. CHASEN
dialogues.text: Yes. I'm sure it must have been very funny. Candy jumps up, pointing out the window behind Mrs. Chase

dialogues.speaker: CANDY
dialogues.text: haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay txt 29/105  3/6/12 62 63 haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay.txt Har -- Haro -- Haroldddd!!! Mrs. Chasen rises, slightly disturbed but used to odd behavior.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. CHASEN
dialogues.text: Yes, dear. Here is Harold now. Harold enters from the side door.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. CHASEN
dialogues.text: (continuing) Candy, this is Harold. Candy is momentarily stunned. Harold nods his greetings.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. CHASEN
dialogues.text: Candy was just telling a funny story about Walter Cronkite. Candy begins hysterical babbling and collapses. INT. MAUDE'S APARTMENT вЂ” DAY The front door opens slowly and Harold enters.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Maude. Maude. Anybody home? He gets no answer and steps into the room. He looks over the fireplace, where a furled umbrella is hung up like a rifle. Nearby he sees a glass cabinet full of sea shells and glass work. He walks over to a large table and is puzzled by the odd-shaped, machine-like boxes on top. He looks over at the wood sculpture, a highly polished work with very smooth curves and holes. Instinctively he puts out his hand to touch it, but decides he shouldn't. He walks over to the piano and examines the silver frames standing on it. They have no photographs in them and this interests him. He goes to the window. Over his shoulder we see MADAME AROUET hoeing in her vegetable patch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A MEDIUM SHOT of Madame Arouet. She is dressed in the black peasant's dress of Southern France. She is thin and wrinkled and wears a large straw sun hat. She is con- tinually working. Harold comes up to her.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Excuse me, have you seen Maude? Madame Arouet looks up. She doesn't comprehend.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay txt
3/6/12 64 65 66 haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay.txt Maude. Do you know where she is? Still no understanding.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Maude?

dialogues.speaker: MADAME AROUET
dialogues.text: Ah! Maude. She points to the building next door.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: (nodding) Oh, thank you. Thank you very much. Merci. He goes off toward the building. Madame Arouet continues hoeing.

dialogues.speaker: MADAME AROUET
dialogues.text: She looks up from her work and watches Harold. There is a strange sadness in her old weathered face - time lost, pleasures past over, the resignation to a lifetime of wor She turns back to her garden.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harold comes through the door, sees where he is at, and becomes embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Oh. Excuse me.

dialogues.speaker: AN ARTIST'S STUDIO
dialogues.text: The first thing we notice is the large block of ice in th center of the room - seven to eight feet tall - and through it, as if looking through the glass on a shower door, we can see a naked female body posing as Venus. The sculptor, GLAUCUS, a frail, little, white-haired old man, dressed in winter clothing, turns from the ice with a chisel and hammer in his gloved hand.

dialogues.speaker: GLAUCUS
dialogues.text: What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I was looking for Maude. The nude figure behind the ice moves and we see her head over the top. It is Maude. haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay txt 31/105 3/6/12 haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay.tx

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: Harold?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Maude?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harold sits in a chair, brooding. Maude is in her kitchen alcove.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: How about some ginger pie?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Eh, fine.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: I'll heat some up. My, it's nice to see you again, Harold. How's your hearse?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Oh, it's fine. Fine.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: She seemed yare to me. Maude lays out the table. Harold gets up. He has some- thing on his mind.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: (nonchalantly) Do you often model for Glaucus?

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: Heavens no! I don't have the time. But I like to keep in practice and poor Glaucus occasionally needs his memory refreshed as to the contours of the female form. (she stops) Do you disapprove?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Me! No. Of course not.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: (she wants the truth) Really. Do you think it's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: (thinks, decides, and reports his haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay txt 32/105. 3/6/12 haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay.tx conclusion) (he smiles)

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: Oh, I'm so happy you said that because I wanted to show you my paintings. This is the "Rape of Rome" and, of course, there in the corner is quite a graphic depiction of Leda and the Swan. Harold looks at the corner of the painting and then back Maude.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: (coquettishly) A self-portrait. (she walks on) But over here is my favorite. It's titled "Rainbow with Egg Underneath and an Elephant." Do you like it?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Yes. Very much.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: It was my last. I then became infatuated with these -- my "Odorifics." She points to the odd-shaped boxes with the tubes and handles attached to them.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: Give the nose a treat, I thought. Have a kind of olfactory banquet! So I began first on the easiest - roast beef, old books, mown grass, then I went on to these - (she reads the labels on the boxes) "An Evening at Maxim's." "Mexican Farmyard." Here's one you'd like. "Snowfall on 42nd Street." Put it on. She helps him put on the oxygen-type mask.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: (continuing) Now I'll pump it up... (she does so) and you just turn the handles. (he does) Okay. What do you smell? haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay txt 33/105  haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay.txt

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Subways... Perfume... Cigarette... (gradually becoming more excited) Cologne... Carpet... Chestnuts! Snow!

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: It goes on and on.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: That's really great. He takes it off.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: Thank you. I thought of continuing - graduating to the abstract and free-smelling - but then I decided to switch to the tactile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gestures at the wood sculpture.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Oh. Eh, I like it.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: No, you have to touch it. (she demonstrates) You have to run your hands over it, get close to it, really reach out and feel. You try it. Harold tries. He gingerly moves his hand over a rather sensuous curve.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: That's right. How's the sensation? A low RISING WHISTLE is heard.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: Oh, that's the kettle. (she goes to kitchen) Go ahead, Harold. Stroke, palm, caress, explore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harold watches Maude leave the room. He hears her invita- tion and looks at the sculpture. A battle is going on inside him. ("Go ahead touch it! - Better not!") Maude begins humming in the kitchen. She won't be out for a whi Harold begins moving his hand over the polished wood. His haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay txt 3/6/12 haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay.tx face is expressionless, but he moves his body closer and his hand becomes more daring. He brings his other hand onto the sculpture. He is enjoying looks at the large hole before him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: e sensations. He is hand moves around it. ("Go ahead - Better not!") His eyes scan the room. Suddenly he sticks his head in the hole, pulls it out, steps back quickly, and looks over to the kitchen. Maude is still out there humming. Harold relaxes, straightens his suit, looks at the sculpture, and braves a short smil Maude enters with the tea.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: Here we are, Harold. Oat straw tea and ginger pie.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Certainly a new experience for me

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: Wonderful! Try something new each day. After all, we're given life to find it out. It doesn't last forever. They sit down at the table.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: You look as if you could.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: Me. Ha! Did I tell you I'll be eighty on Saturday?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: You don't look eighty.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: That's the influence of the right food, the right exercise, and the breathing. (she gestures) Greet the dawn with the Breath of Fire! (the demonstration leaves her a little winded) Of course, there's no doubt the body is giving out. I'm well into autumn. I'll have to be giving it all up after Saturday. Sweeten the tea with honey, Harold. It's delicious.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: That's a nice teapot. haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay txt right
3/6/12 haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay.tx

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: Sterling silver. It was my dear mother-in-law's, part of a dinner set of fifty pieces. It's one of the few things that survived. (pause) Oh, but I do rattle on so. Tell me about yourself, Harold. (she settles back with her tea) What do you do when you aren't visiting funerals?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shots of falling buildings. The giant demolition ball swings left and right knocking mighty holes in brick wall and sending them crumbling to earth with deafening noise.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: Harold and Maude watch, in the background, an old buildin collapse into rubble. After the noise abates Maude turns to Harold.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: Yes. There is definitely a certain attraction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A giant crane comes crashing into the hood of a car. The car is picked up and dropped on a conveyor belt which hauls it up to the crusher. Despite the terrible din Harold and Maude watch with rapt attention.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: Harold and Maude are sitting on a hill picnicking. They are looking at the junkyard operation in the distance. They chew for a while then Maude offers Harold a raw carr She chews on one herself.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: Well, it's all very thrilling, of course, but I ask you, Harold... Is it enough?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: What do you mean? Maude smiles. haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay txt 36/105 3/6/12 haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay.tx

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CAMERA is at a LOW LEVEL. We see long rows of young plants that stretch into the distance. We PAN across the field into two giant CLOSEUPS of Harold and Maude. They are lying on the ground looking intently at one little plant. Maude looks over to Harold.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: I love to watch things grow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHOTS of flowers growing, all different varieties, in clusters, in pots, on vines, in greenhouses, in large fields. Maude and Harold are walking down a row of flowers.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: They grow and bloom, and fade, and die, and some change into something else. Ah, life! They stop by some flowers.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: I should like to change into a sunflower most of all. They are so tall and simple. And you, Harold, what flower would you like to be?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I don't know. Just one of those. (he gestures)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see a large field of daisies stretching to the hills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harold and Maude look out at it.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: (a little perturbed) Why do you say that?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: (softly) Because they are all the same. haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay txt 37/105  3/6/12 716 717 haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay.txt

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: Oooh, but they are not. Look. They bend down to see some close ones.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: (continuing) See - some are smaller, some are fatter, some grow to the left, some to the right, some even have some petals missing - all kinds of observable differences, and we haven't even touched the bio- chemical. You see, Harold, they're like the Japanese. At first you think they all look alike, but after you get to know them you see there is not a repeat in the bunch. Each person is different, never existed before and never to exist again. Just like this daisy - (she picks it) - an individual. They stand up.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Well, we may be individuals all right but - (he looks out at the field) - we have to grow up together. Maude looks up. She is very struck by what Harold said. She speaks very softly and we see she has tears in her ey

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: Yes, that's very true. Still I believe much of the world's sorrow comes from people who know they are this - (she holds the daisy) - yet let themselves be treated - (she looks out at the field) - as that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thousands and thousands of daisies wave gently in the breeze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay txt 38/105.  3/6/12 718 80 haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay. txt A large black Continental apparently out of control crashes through the flower farm fence, swerves onto the road, and zigzags away at top speed before finally straightening out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harold is petrified. Maude is driving. She looks over at him and explains.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: Ha! Power steering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Continental speeds by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harold has somewhat recovered.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Boy, Maude. The way you handle cars. I'd never handle a car like that.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: Oh, it's only a machine, Harold. It's not as if it were alive, like a horse or a camel. We may live in a machine age, but I simply can't treat them as equals. (she looks over at the radio) Of course, the age has its advantages. She turns it on. Music plays softly.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: (continuing) The universal language of mankind. (she begins humming along with the tune) What music do you like, Harold?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Well... Harold is suddenly thrown against the door as Maude makes a fast U-turn. haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay txt 39/105.  3/6/12 81 82 83 haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay.txt

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see the Continental turn across the street, drive up onto the sidewalk, and stop as it bumps into a telegraph pole.

dialogues.speaker: THE CAR
dialogues.text: Maude gets out, walks around the car, and opens Harold's door. Harold, very shaken, gets out.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: (she points) Look.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: Over there by the courthouse.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: That little tree. It's in trouble. Come on. Maude walks over to the courthouse. Harold, not wanting t be left with the crashed car, quickly follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They come to a little tree growing in the garden.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: Look at it, Harold. It's suffocating. It's the smog. People can live with it, but it gives trees asthma. They can't breathe. See the leaves are all brown. Harold, we've got to do something about this life.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: But what?

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: We'll transplant it. To the forest. haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay txt 40/105.  3/6/12 84 haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay.txt

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: But we can't just dig it up!

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: But this is public property.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: Exactly. She's ready to dig.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Don't you think we should get some tools, maybe?

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: Yes, you're right. We'll go see Glaucus. Come on.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Oh, wai Maude. Look!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harold points and we see that two COPS have stopped and a checking out the Continental on the sidewalk.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: (nonchalantly) Oh, the police. Come on.

dialogues.speaker: BY THE CONTINENTAL
dialogues.text: The police are looking around. Maude boldly walks by. Harold tags reluctantly along.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: Good afternoon, Officer. Bit of trouble here?

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER
dialogues.text: (tips his hat) Yes, ma'am. Somebody had some trouble parking.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: Well, it's a tricky turn.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER
dialogues.text: (not understanding but amiable) Eh, yes, ma'm.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: Tell me -- haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay txt 41/105. 3/6/12 haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay.tx (points to car in front) -- is that car parked all right?

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER
dialogues.text: Oh yes. That's fine.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: Well, thank you. Eh, officer, you might turn off the radio. Saves the battery. Maude and Harold walk off to the car in front. The office turns off the radio. He looks up. Maude has opened the door of the car in front with her ring of keys. She waves to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He tips his hat and waves back. He is smiling as we hear the engine start. The smile drops as we hear Maude's screeching start.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maude and Harold enter. The block of ice in the center of the room is now five to six feet tall and melting rapidly into the large trough in which it stands. Around the stud on the walls and benches are every conceivable hand tool sculpting tools, gardening tools, construction tools, etc On a raised platform in one corner covered with rugs and cushions and skins, lies Glaucus, bundled up in a parka and snoring horribly. In his gloved hands he holds a hammer and an ice pick.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: Oh, my. We're too late.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Is he all right?

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: He's fallen asleep, as usual. She covers him with a rug.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: (continuing) We'll come back in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: What is that he's working on?

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: An ice sculpture. It's Venus haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay txt 42/105 3/6/12 haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay.tx the Goddess of Love, the completion of which is his unfulfilled dream.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: It is kind of rough.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: He's never finished one yet. He has around him every kind of hand tool known to man, but the poor dear has difficulty staying awake.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Look, the ice is melting.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: Yes. They both stand and stare.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: That's one of the drawbacks of the medium.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harold and Maude sit before the fire. They have just finished dinner.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: A little after-dinner liqueur, Harold?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Well, I really don't drink...

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: Oh, it's all right. It's organic. She pours.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: (offering) Some nuts? Some licorice? It has no nutritional value but then consistency is not really a human trait.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Thank you. He chews the licorice. He gestures above the fireplace. haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay txt 43/105  3/6/12 haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay.txt

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: (continuing) What's that?

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: My umbrella? (fluttery laugh) Oh, that's just a relic. I found it when I was packing to come to America. It used to be my defense on picket lines and rallies and political meetings - being dragged off by police or attacked by thugs of the opposition. (fluttery laugh as she remembers) A long time ago.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: What were you fighting for?

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: Oh, Big Issues. Liberty. Rights. Justice. Kings died and kingdoms fell. I don't regret the kingdoms - what sense in borders and nations and patriotism - but I do miss the kings. When I was a little girl I was taken to the palace in Vienna, to a garden party. I can still see the sunshine, the parasols, and the flashing uniforms of the young officers. I thought then I would marry a soldier. (fluttery laugh) Later, Frederick would chide me about it. (with a twinkle) He was so serious. A doctor at the University. And in the government. Suddenly she gets quiet.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: But, that was all... before... Maude stares into the fire. She suddenly seems very small and fragile. Harold notices the change that has come over her and is not sure what to say.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: So you don't use the umbrella any more? looks at him and says softly: haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay txt 44/105  3/6/12 haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay.txt

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: No more revolts.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: (sparks back to her old self) Oh, yes! Every day. But I don't need a defense anymore. I embrace! Still fighting for the Big Issues but now in my small, individual way. Shall we have a song?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Well, I don't...

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: Oh come on. I'll teach you. She goes to the piano, sits down, and plays. It is a fast delightful song and she sings it with zest.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: Come on, Harold, join in the chorus. Beside her Harold hesitatingly sings along. The o.s. orchestra has joined in, enabling Maude to leave the pian and get up and dance. She capers in true old vaudeville fashion. As the song continues we go into a MONTAGE and see Maude dance as she sings in various locales - the bea the forest, the fields, the hills, finally returning to her room to join up with Harold for a socko finish.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: Oh, that was fun. Let's play something together.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: But I don't play anything.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: (a bombshell!) Don't play anything! Dear me. Everyone should be able to make some music. Why, it's life! - Rhythm and harmony - That's the cosmic dance. Come with me. She goes over to a large cupboard and opens both doors. It is full of all kinds of musical instruments. She ferre about for a while and pulls out a banjo.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay txt 45/105. 3/6/12 haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay.tx Here we are. Just the thing. She shows him a chord and how to strum. - "Your fingers here... etc." He does it a few times.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: That's right. But be impulsive! Be fanciful! Let the music flow out of you as freely as though you were talking. Okay? (she sits) From the top -- Let's jam! She swings into the chorus and Harold strums along. At th end she looks over at him beaming.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Okay?

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: Superb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harold sits practicing his banjo. We barely recognize tha he is playing Maude's Song. He hears his mother calling him and he quickly hides his banjo in a nearby flower pot His mother enters.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. CHASEN
dialogues.text: Harold! Harold! Ah, there you are. I have a little present for you. A surprise. Come with me. They both go off toward the garage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They both come around the corner and Mrs. Chasen gestures dramatically in front of her.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. CHASEN
dialogues.text: There!

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: We see a little green MG roadster. Harold comes up to it, suspecting something funny. He looks around for his hearse.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. CHASEN
dialogues.text: Isn't that darling? I had them tow off that black monstrous thing of haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay txt 46/105  3/6/12 91 92 93 94 haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay. txt yours and had them send this around instead. It's so much more appropriate for you, don't you think? Harold starts to say something.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. CHASEN
dialogues.text: (continuing) One more thing, Harold. I've talked on the phone with your second computer date and she seems a very nice, quiet girl. Not at all hysterical like the first one. Nevertheless I want you to be on your best behavior when she comes tomorrow and make her feel at home. (she looks at the car before leaving) Cute little thing, isn't it? I like it very much. (she exits) Harold stands for a moment looking at the MG. He makes a decision.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harold takes off his jacket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harold wheels to the car a large acetylene torch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harold pulls down a great welding mask over his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A brand new block of ice - eight to nine feet tall - stands in the trough in the center of the studio. Glaucus spryly dressed for autumn, is chipping merrily away.

dialogues.speaker: GLAUCUS
dialogues.text: Come in. Come in. Maude enters.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: Have you seen Harold?

dialogues.speaker: GLAUCUS
dialogues.text: haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay txt 47/105 3/6/12 haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay.tx One moment. He makes a chip on the ice and stands back to examine it. He is satisfied. He turns to Maude, full of pep.

dialogues.speaker: GLAUCUS
dialogues.text: Ah, Dame Marjorie. Greetings. (he kisses her hand) As Odysseus said to Penelope... Harold enters a little out of breath.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Sorry I'm late.

dialogues.speaker: GLAUCUS
dialogues.text: A rather free translation but nonetheless correct. Greetings to you too, my little one. (he gestures at the ice) Tell me, what do you see?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: A block of ice.

dialogues.speaker: GLAUCUS
dialogues.text: Exactly! Now, ask me what I see.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: What do you see?

dialogues.speaker: GLAUCUS
dialogues.text: I see the eternal goddess of beauty and love. I see Aphrodi The consummate woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Full of warmth and fire. Frozen. (to the ice) And it is I who shall set you free. He takes a small pneumatic drill and attacks the ice. He makes a little incision, puts it down, and steps back to observe. He wipes his brow.

dialogues.speaker: GLAUCUS
dialogues.text: Each morning I am delivered of a new block of ice. Each evening my eyes grow weary, my hands hang heavy, and I am swept down Lethe to slumber - (slowly with feeling) - while my goddess, half-born, drips away - unseen, unsung, and unknown. haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay txt 48/105  3/6/12 95 96 97 98 haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay.txt

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: May we borrow a shovel?

dialogues.speaker: GLAUCUS
dialogues.text: Wait! Let me think. Do I need a shovel today? No! I needa blowtorch. (he gets a blowtorch) Take any shovel. You are welcome. Harold picks up a shovel.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: Thank you, Glaucus. We'll see you later. Come on, Harold. Harold and Maude exit.

dialogues.speaker: GLAUCUS
dialogues.text: Farewell, my friends. (he fires the blowtorch) "Where'er he moved, the goddess shone before" - Homer! He approaches the ice.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: We PAN with a brown pick-up truck as it drives along. A small tree stands swaying in the back.

dialogues.speaker: SIDE
dialogues.text: Maude is driving. Harold sits beside her. The car is traveling from SCREEN LEFT to SCREEN RIGHT. Harold looks at Maude. She smiles. He smiles.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: Cop on a motorcycle watches Maude go by. He follows her and flags her down. She pulls the truck over to the side of the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cop gets off his motorcycle and comes over to the tru door.

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: Lady, you were going 70 miles an hour in a 45-mile zone. Could haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay txt 49/105  3/6/12 haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay.txt I see your license, please?

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: Yes. Those little pieces of paper with your picture on it?

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: Oh, I don't have one. CoP Come again.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: I don't have one. I don't believe in them. cop How long have you been driving?

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: About forty-five minutes, wouldn't you say, Harold? We were hoping to start sooner but, you see, it's rather hard to find a truck.

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: Could I see your registration?

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: I just don't think we have one, unless it's in the glove compartment. Could you look, Harold?

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: Isn't this your vehicle?

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: No, no. I just took it.

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: Took it?

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: Yes. You see I have to plant my tree.

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: Your tree.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: Well, s not really mine. I dug it up in front of the courthouse. We're transplanting it. Letting

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay txt 50/105.  3/6/12 99 101 haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay. txt it breathe, you know. But, of course, we would like to get it into soil, as soon as possible.

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: Lady, let me get this straight.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: (agreeing) All right, then, and we'll be off. (she revs up the motor) Nice chatting with you. Maude zooms off down the highway. The cop is left flabber gasted. He races for his motorcycle. With SIRENS blazing he drives of to catch her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harold looks uneasily out the back window.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I think he's following us.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: Is he? Ah, the police. Always wanting to play games. Well, here goes. Maude accelerates and zooms off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maude careens down the highway dodging cars. The cop follows in hot pursuit. Suddenly Maude does a full left turn making a screeching half-circle and charging off dow the highway in the opposite direction. Cars pull over out of her way. The cop does a similar U-turn and follows her Maude immediately makes another U-turn and flies off down the highway in her original direction. The cop is taken unawares. Traffic around him is in total confusion. He dodges zigzagging cars, runs up onto the embankment, and stops.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: (turns around badly shaken) He's stopped.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: (brightly) The old double U-turn. Gets haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay txt
3/6/12 104 105 haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay.txt them every time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The truck continues on its merry way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maude and Harold have just finished planting the tree; Maude is putting the finishing touches around the trunk. She stands up.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: There. Oh, I like the feel of soil, don't you? And the smell. It's the earth. "The earth is my body. My head is in the stars." (little laugh) Who said that?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: I suppose I did. (laughs) Well, farewell little tree. Grow up tall, and change, and fall to replenish the earth. Isn't it wonderful, Harold? All around us. ings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Living t

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harold and Maude are sitting in a tree.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE

dialogues.text: (smokes) I'm sure picking up on vices.

dialogues.text: Vice? Virtue? It's best not to be too moral. You cheat yourself out of too much life. Aim above morality. As Confucius says, "Don't simply be good. Make good things happen."

dialogues.text: You are the wisest person I know.

dialogues.text: Me! (she laughs and shakes her head) When I look around me I know I know nothing. I remember though, once long ago in Persia, we met a wise man in the bazaar. He was a professional and used to sell his wisdom to anyone willing to pay. His specialty for tourists was a maxim engraved on the head of a pin. "The wisest," he said, "the truest, the most instructive words for all men at all times." Frederick bought one for me and back at the hotel I peered through a magnifying glass to read the words - "And this too shall pass away." (fluttery laugh) Well, the wise man was right - if you remember that, you can't help but live life fully.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Yes. I haven't lived. (he suddenly giggles) I've died a few times.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: (he smiles) Okay. Partly because of the pot, but mostly because he has foun a friend, Harold opens up for the first time in his life. As he gets into the story he tells it with such animation and delight that we are amazed at all the fun and zest he has kept locked up inside him.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Well, the first time it wasn't even planned. It was when I was at boarding school and they were getting ready for the school Centennial Celebration and they put all the fireworks and food and stuff in this room in the West Wing. Well, on the floor above they had the Chemistry Lab and I had to stay in and clean it up. So I thought I'd doa little experimenting. I got all this stuff out and began mixing it up. It was very scientific. I was measuring the amounts. Well, suddenly there was this big fizzing sound and this white kind of porridge stuff began erupting out of the beaker, and moving along the desk and falling onto the floor. It was making an awful mess. So I got the hose to try to spray it haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay txt 59/105  3/6/12 haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay. txt into the sink. I turned on the water and - POW! There was this massive explosion. Knocked me down. Blew out the floor. Boards and brick and flames leaping up. Singed my hair. Smoke everywhere. I got up, then this sound like bombs going off. It was the fireworks in the room below. And all this stuff came flying out the hole. PACHAU! Skyrockets and pinwheels. And fire balls all whizzing and bouncing. And I was just standing there stunned - I couldn't believe it - just watching - being pelted by all these little pellets - turns out to be the goddamn popcorn spewed up from below. The whole place was a crazy inferno with the rockets and everything, and I couldn't get to the door. But behind me was this old laundry chute, so I hopped in that and slid down that to the basement. When I got outside I saw that the whole top of the building was on fire and, of course, it was pandemonium with people running around and fire alarms ringing. So I decided to go home. When I get there my mother is having this big party so I creep up the back stairs to my room. Then there is this ring on the doorbell. It's the police. I creep over to the banister to see what they say, and they tell my mother that I had been killed in a fire at school. Well, everyone got very quiet.
