dialogues.text: Oh, Harold. You are so young. She strokes his hair. The tears continue to fall.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: (continuing) What have they taught you? Yes. I cry. I cry for you. I cry for this. (the visa) I cry at beauty - a first snow, a rose, a sunset. As she talks through her tears, Harold is very moved. He takes her hand.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: (continuing) I cry when a man tortures his brother... when he repents and begs forgiveness... when forgiveness is refused... and haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay txt 87/105  3/6/12 138 139 142 143 haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay. txt when it is granted. To cry is to laugh. To laugh is to cry . a uniquely human trait. And the main thing in life, my dear Harold, is not to be afraid to be human. They sit facing each other on the end of the bed. We see from the bed the fire glowing behind them. Harold brushes the tears from her eyes. He leans forward and kisses her lightly on the lips. They part for a moment. Then both lean forward and kiss again, break and fall back onto the bed and OUT OF CAMERA. The CAMERA ZOOMS SLOWLY FORWARD into the fire. HOLD.

dialogues.speaker: WITH MUSIC
dialogues.text: A lot of the sequence is soft focus, blurred edges, and supered with colored carnival lights. The images are not meant to appear overtly sexual but rather - lyrically sensual - and fun!

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD AND MAUDE
dialogues.text: together in a Ferris Wheel as it begins to rise to the heights.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD AND MAUDE ON A MERRY-GO-ROUND
dialogues.text: holding hands across the aisle as their horses alternatel go up and down.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD AND MAUDE
dialogues.text: on a roller coaster as it speeds around a curve and plunges downhill. As it speeds around another curve we burst into:

dialogues.speaker: FIREWORKS
dialogues.text: A hundred skyrockets bursting in air, with much NOISE. The noise fades.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD AND MAUDE
dialogues.text: lying on the grass, looking up at the fireworks reflected in their faces. Their heads are nestled against each haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay txt 88/105  3/6/12 144 146 haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay. txt other's shoulders. They look at each other and smile. Harold lifts his outside arm and lays it around his head. Maude puts her outside hand in his. They hold this position and stare into each other's eyes, as the CAMERA BEGINS A VERTICAL RISE.

dialogues.speaker: THE FIRE IN MAUDE'S APARTMENT
dialogues.text: at the same CAMERA POSITION that we went out on. The fire is now out. The grate is cold. It is daylight. We HEAR a cock crow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIGHT SHOT of a hand picking cigarette ash into an ash- tray. We PAN over and see that it is Harold sitting up in bed, bare-chested, casually smoking. He takes a deep drag and blows the smoke out in a manner that is decidedl sexual. He smiles and looks down to his left. We PAN OVER to include Maude lying beside him, the covers demurely pulled up to her chin. She catches Harold's smile and blushes coyly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Chasen is on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. CHASEN
dialogues.text: Fay, darling, I know Rene will be furious but if you knew what I've had to put up with in the last couple of days... Harold enters.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Mother.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. CHASEN
dialogues.text: Not now, Harold... (into the phone) You can't put me down for Monday?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Mother.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. CHASEN
dialogues.text: Harold, please! I'm on the phone. haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay txt 89/105.  3/6/12 148 haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay. txt

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Mother. I'm going to get married.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. CHASEN
dialogues.text: Fay, I'll call you back. (she hangs up) What did you say?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I'm getting married.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. CHASEN
dialogues.text: (pause) To whom?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: To a girl. Here. He takes his wallet with the series of photos on it, flips to one, and hands it to Mrs. Chasen. She looks at it for a moment. She looks up.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. CHASEN
dialogues.text: I suppose you think this is very funny, Harold.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. CHASEN
dialogues.text: A sunflower? She hands Harold back the wallet. It is indeed the picture of a large sunflower, clipped from a dealer's catalog. Harold, a little ruffled, finds the correct photo of Maude and hands it to his mother. Mrs. Chasen examines it. She squints her eyes to clear her vision and looks again.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. CHASEN
dialogues.text: (in a strained voice) You can't be serious?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: He smiles proudly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Chasen is lying on the couch. She turns to the psychiatrist.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. CHASEN
dialogues.text: haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay txt 90/105  3/6/12 150 151 haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay.txt He's serious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uncle Victor sits at his desk. A picture of the Presi- dent of the United States is over his right shoulder. He is addressing the camera as the President addresses the nation.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE VICTOR
dialogues.text: (a painful confrontation) Harold, your mother has spoken to me about your marriage plan, and though normally I have nothing against marriage, I don't think this is eh... quite normal. Now, I don't want to remind you of the unpleasant ident that occurred the other day. I think it is best if we consider that forgotten. But I do think that it would be wisest for you not to leave the house or indulge in any kind of activity that would be newsworthy. This marriage would attract attention, and, frankly Harold, I don't think you need a wife. You need a nurse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: n

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The psychiatrist sits at his desk. A picture of Sigmund Freud is over his right shoulder. He too seems to be addressing the nation.

dialogues.speaker: PSYCHIATRIST
dialogues.text: There's no doubt, Harold, this impending marriage adds another chapter to an already fascinating case. But let us examine it, and I think you'll realize there is a simple Freudian explanation for your romantic attachment to this older woman. It is known as the Oedipus Complex, a very common neurosis, particularly in this society, whereby the male child subconsciously wishes to sleep with his mother. Of course, what puzzles me, Harold, is that you want to sleep with your grandmother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay txt 91/105.  3/6/12 152 153 154 haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay. txt It is the same little old priest we have met earlier He sits at his desk and addresses the camera like a TV audience. A picture of the Pope is over his right shoulder; a picture of Jesus Christ over his left.

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST
dialogues.text: (very reasoned and slow) Now, Harold, the Church has nothing against the union of the old and the young. Each age has its own beauty. But a marital union is concerned with the conjugal rights. And the procreation of children. I would be remiss in my duties if I did not tell you that the idea of -- (he swallows) - intercourse - the fact of your young, firm -- (growing disturbed) - body commingling with the withered flesh, sagging breasts, and flabby buttocks - makes me -- (falls apart) - want to vomit.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD.
dialogues.text: But you didn't ask if I love her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: of Uncle Victor, the psychiatrist, and the priest, as they register a chagrined reaction to Harold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CLOSEUP HAROLD in Shot 152 is PULLED BACK to include Mrs. Chasen.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. CHASEN
dialogues.text: Love? Love? What do you know about her? Where does she come from? Where did you meet her?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: At a funeral.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. CHASEN
dialogues.text: Oh... That's wonderful... I haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay txt 92/105. 3/6/12 haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay.tx get an eighty-year-old pallbearer for a daughter-in-law! Be reasonable, Harold! You're dealing with your life! What will people say?!

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I don't care what people say.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. CHASEN
dialogues.text: You don't care! "Miss Shroud of 1890 Weds the Boy of a Thousand Deaths!" Listen to me... Harold gets up to go.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. CHASEN
dialogues.text: What are you doing, Harold? You can't leave me. She follows him to the door.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. CHASEN
dialogues.text: (continuing) Where are you going? He turns at the door.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I'm going to marry the woman I love.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. CHASEN
dialogues.text: Harold! A pause.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. CHASEN
dialogues.text: (continuing; quietly) This is insane.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Perhaps it is. He leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the hallway Harold and Maude are giggling as Harold finishes putting a blindfold around Maude's eyes.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I hope that isn't too tight. Okay. Here we go. haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay txt 93/105. 3/6/12 haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay.tx He opens the door leading her by the hand.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: Oh, I love surprises! Makes me feel so - chiffon!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door opens and Harold leads in Maude. He stands Maude in front of the CAMERA and with theatrical bravado removes the handkerchief. She blinks and looks around. A radiant joy fills her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is filled with over a hundred sunflowers. Hanging over the fireplace is a banner saying:

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: Oh, Harold, it is dazzling. They are all so... so beautiful! Harold begins humming the Love Waltz.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: This way, m'lady. He dances Maude over to the table.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: (continuing) Supper for two.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: Oh, you've thought of everyt. And champagne.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: (imitating her) It's all right. It's organic.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: Oh, Harold. (fluttery laugh)

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: For you. He hands her a single daisy in a vase. Maude takes out the daisy and smiles. haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay txt 94/105.  3/6/12 159 161 haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay.txt

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: (continuing) And after dinner, one more surprise.... He puts a tiny ring box on the table.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: (continuing) which I hope will make you very happy.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: Oh, I am happy, Harold. Ecstatically happy. I couldn't imagine a lovelier farewell.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Farewell?

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: Why yes. It's my eightieth birthday.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: But you're not going anywhere, are you?

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: Oh yes, dear. I took the pills an hour ago. I should be gone by midnight.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: He can't believe it.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: She smiles.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: He believes it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With SIRENS WAILING, an ambulance tears around a corner. Cars pull over as it speeds down the street. haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay txt 95/105. 3/6/12 haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay.tx

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maude is lying down. She holds the daisy in her hand. She would be perfectly happy but for her concern over Harold, who is highly overwrought and crying desperately. He is kneeling beside her. The SIRENS WAIL loudly outside.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: Oh, Harold! What a fuss this is. (fluttery laugh) So unnecessary.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Maude, please. Don't die. I couldn't bear it. Please, don't die.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: But, Harold, we begin to die as soon as we are born. What is so strange about death? It's no surprise. It's part of life. It's change.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: But why now?

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: I thought eighty was a good round number. She giggles.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: (continuing) I feel giddy.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: But Maude, you don't understand. I love you. Do you hear me? I've never said that to anyone in my life before. You're the first. Maude. Please don't leave me.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: Oh, Harold, don't upset yourself so.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: It's true. I can't live without you.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: (smiles warmly) haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay txt 96/105.  3/6/12 164 165 haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay.txt "And this too shall pass away."

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Never! Never! I'll never forget you. I wanted to marry you. Don't you understand! I love you. I love you!

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: Oh! That's wonderful, Harold. Go - and love some more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ambulance SCREAMS in and stops. The two attendants open up the back. They slide Maude onto a gurney and wheel her toward the door.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Hold on, Maude! Hold on! We'll be there soon. Please, just hold on. He runs ahead.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: Hold on? Hold on? (fluttery laugh) Oh, Harold, how absurd. Harold goes to push open the doors. They open auto- matically. Maude is wheeled through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A feisty, old, redheaded NURSE is explaining operations to a rather simpleminded STUDENT NURSE. A GANGLING INTERN with horn-rimmed glasses looks on. Maude enters on the gurney. The ambulance men move off to the back counter and talk as they fill out their forms. Harold is almost hysterical. Maude, on the other hand, is very calm. She holds the daisy and hums to herself Maude's Song. (NOTE: This scene goes very fast with much of the dialogue dovetailed and ad libs overlapping in the background.)

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Please. There's been an haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay txt 97/105  3/6/12 haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay.txt accident, an overdose of pills We've got to see a doctor. It's an emergency.

dialogues.speaker: HEAD NURSE
dialogues.text: All right, now go ahead and get the particulars.

dialogues.speaker: STUDENT NURSE
dialogues.text: Eh, what's your name?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: It's not me. It's her.

dialogues.speaker: HEAD NURSE
dialogues.text: It's better to begin by asking last name first, then first name, then middle name or initial, if any. It saves time.

dialogues.speaker: STUDENT NURSE
dialogues.text: What is your last name?

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: Chardin. Dame Marjorie. But you may call me Maude.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Please! She has got to see a doctor right away.

dialogues.speaker: HEAD NURSE
dialogues.text: Young man, perhaps you ought to wait in the waiting room.

dialogues.speaker: STUDENT NURSE
dialogues.text: How old are you?

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: Eighty. It's my birthday.

dialogues.speaker: STUDENT NURSE
dialogues.text: Oh, many happy returns.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: No. I don't think so.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: You don't understand. She's taken an overdose of pills two hours ago. She hasn't got much time. The intern creeps round from behind.

dialogues.speaker: INTERN
dialogues.text: haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay txt 98/105.  3/6/12 haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay.txt Could I have your signature on this? It's just a formality.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: Delighted! I like your hair so much. She signs.

dialogues.speaker: INTERN
dialogues.text: It's in case of damage claims, you know, so we - the hospital - won't be responsible for...

dialogues.speaker: HEAD NURSE
dialogues.text: (to student nurse) Always use a ballpoint pen. It's more efficient.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Please, don't you realize? She is dying.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: Well, not dying, actually. I'm changing. You know, like from winter to spring. Of course, it is a big step to take.

dialogues.speaker: INTERN
dialogues.text: Not that anything regrettable is going to happen. It's just regulations .

dialogues.speaker: HEAD NURSE
dialogues.text: Well, then, perhaps you'd better skip the preliminaries and get to the important section.

dialogues.speaker: STUDENT NURSE
dialogues.text: All right. Ah, what is your Social Security number?

dialogues.speaker: INTERN
dialogues.text: Purely a legal safeguard. Nothing personal, you understand.

dialogues.speaker: HEAD NURSE
dialogues.text: No. Ask about the insurance. The hospital insurance.

dialogues.speaker: STUDENT NURSE
dialogues.text: Do you have any insurance? Blue Cross? Blue Shield?

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay txt 99/105.  3/6/12 haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay.txt Insurance against what?

dialogues.speaker: STUDENT NURSE
dialogues.text: No insurance. She notes it down.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: This is madness.

dialogues.speaker: HEAD NURSE
dialogues.text: I'm sorry but there is always a two-hour wait for the psychiatrist.

dialogues.speaker: INTERN
dialogues.text: It's nothing personal. It's my job. A DOCTOR and TWO NURSES enter.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: What's the trouble?

dialogues.speaker: HEAD NURSE
dialogues.text: An overdose of drugs

dialogues.speaker: STUDENT NURSE
dialogues.text: Do you have a welfare plan at your place of employment?

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: I'm retired.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Doctor, please. She has taken these pills. You've got to do something

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: All right. Take her in there. They start wheeling her away.

dialogues.speaker: INTERN
dialogues.text: It's nothing personal.

dialogues.speaker: STUDENT NURSE
dialogues.text: And who's the next of kin?

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: Humanity... She holds the daisy in her hand. She waves to Harold as they push her through the doors.

dialogues.speaker: MAUDE
dialogues.text: haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay txt 100/105.  3/6/12 168 170 173 haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay.txt Farewell, Harold. It's been all such fun. The doors swing shut. She is gone. Harold stands alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA LOCKED DOWN. Harold sits on a couch. To his right is a window, to his left a chair and a lighted lamp. He waits.

dialogues.speaker: SHOT
dialogues.text: Harold sits in the chair. He waits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harold stands by the window. It is dawn. The lights go out. It is daylight. We HEAR the laughter of a baby.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: He is looking out the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Down on the lawn we see a MOTHER playing with her BABY. He is squealing with delight as she lifts him high into the air again and again.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: of the mother and the laughing baby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Harold standing forlorn at the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doctor comes up to speak to him. The doctor shakes his head. haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay txt 101/105 3/6/12 haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay.tx

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harold turns back to the window. The doctor leaves All the time the baby is laughing.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: We see Harold through the window screen. He is crying. He can HEAR the baby's laughter. He turns and walks away. 176 INT. HOSPITAL CORRIDOR вЂ” DAY Harold is crying. He walks down the hospital corridor.

dialogues.speaker: THE MATERNITY WARD
dialogues.text: He passes the maternity ward. Laughing parents pointing at screaming infants. Their noise overrides the laughing baby and joins the rising intensity of the MUSIC.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO HAROLD
dialogues.text: Harold walks faster. His face is drawn with pain and tear We TRACK before him. He looks left and sees:

dialogues.speaker: A WOMAN
dialogues.text: in a room, delirious with pain.

dialogues.speaker: A MAN
dialogues.text: in disheveled pajamas walks from his room like a bewildered child, dribbling food down his front.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO HAROLD
dialogues.text: He keeps walking fast. He looks right and sees:

dialogues.speaker: A FAMILY GROUP
dialogues.text: who have just been told of a death. They cry in each other's arms. A TEN-YEAR-OLD BOY confused, looks up at them, and haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay txt 102/10  3/6/12 187 189 190 191 haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay.txt begins to sob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harold's mini hearse swerves around the corner at high speed. Dust rises and tires screech. On the TRACK the crying has stopped but the MUSIC is building to a new climax.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harold, ignoring the tears rolling down his cheeks, grips the wheel hard and drives like a man with an unrelenting purpose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see them from the car window.

dialogues.speaker: THE CAR
dialogues.text: dangerously close to the edge.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: He seems possessed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The road rushes past as we maneuver around treacherous curves.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: He makes a sudden right-hand turn and drives out on a promontory toward the sea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see dirt and grass race beneath us - haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay txt 103/105  3/6/12 195 200 haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay.txt We bump over rocks -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see the edge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We reach the edge of the cliff - we plunge off into space....

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: The little hearse falls from the cliff, crashing at the bottom, and bursting into flame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We look down at the burning vehicle. We HOLD and watch it burn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gradually the fire dies down. Suddenly we hear the fumbled pluckings of Maude's Song on a banjo. It stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We PAN up left and there is Harold as large as life. He takes a look over the cliff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His hearse is still quietly burning.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO HAROLD
dialogues.text: He wipes his nose with the back of his hand and tries again on the banjo. He barely gets the melody started before he is lost. Summoning up all his concentration, he tries again, and this time he manages to get the fingering right. He continues playing and turns away from the edge.

dialogues.speaker: FRONT OF HAROLD
dialogues.text: haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay txt 104/10  3/6/12 haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay.txt He started slow but now he is gradually beginning to play the song in its original upbeat tempo. He gets better and better at it. The song is very catching and Harold's tear-stained face registers what could be a smile. He walks by the CAMERA and we turn with him, and HOLD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A full orchestra joins in the playing and we watch Harold amble down the road, strumming along, until he is only a small figure in the distance. FADE OUT.

dialogues.speaker: THE END
dialogues.text: Screenplay by Colin Higgins 5/29/70 haroldandmaudehomepage.com/xhigginnsscreenplay txt 105/105.
